<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of digest_calc_hash:
```c
_MHD_static_inline void
digest_calc_hash (struct DigestAlgorithm *da, uint8_t *digest)
{
  mhd_assert (! da->uninitialised);
  mhd_assert (da->algo_selected);
  mhd_assert (da->ready_for_hashing);
#ifdef MHD_MD5_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_MD5 == da->algo)
  {
#ifdef MHD_MD5_HAS_FINISH
    MHD_MD5_finish (&da->ctx.md5_ctx, digest);
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = false;
#endif /* _DEBUG */
#else  /* ! MHD_MD5_HAS_FINISH */
    MHD_MD5_finish_reset (&da->ctx.md5_ctx, digest);
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = true;
#endif /* _DEBUG */
#endif /* ! MHD_MD5_HAS_FINISH */
  }
  else
#endif /* MHD_MD5_SUPPORT */
#ifdef MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA256 == da->algo)
  {
#ifdef MHD_SHA256_HAS_FINISH
    MHD_SHA256_finish (&da->ctx.sha256_ctx, digest);
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = false;
#endif /* _DEBUG */
#else  /* ! MHD_SHA256_HAS_FINISH */
    MHD_SHA256_finish_reset (&da->ctx.sha256_ctx, digest);
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = true;
#endif /* _DEBUG */
#endif /* ! MHD_SHA256_HAS_FINISH */
  }
  else
#endif /* MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT */
#ifdef MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA512_256 == da->algo)
  {
    MHD_SHA512_256_finish (&da->ctx.sha512_256_ctx, digest);
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = false;
#endif /* _DEBUG */
  }
  else
#endif /* MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT */
  mhd_assert (0);   /* Should not happen */
#ifdef _DEBUG
  da->hashing = false;
#endif /* _DEBUG */
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Recursion (direct or indirect) can only occur via function or function-like macro calls. The listed fragments are all call sites (including assertion macros and algorithm-specific finish/reset calls) and therefore must be inspected to ensure none call digest_calc_hash (directly or through a call chain). Other parts of the function (preprocessor conditionals, if/else selectors, assignments such as da->ready_for_hashing = false/true, da->hashing = false, variable references, and comments) do not perform calls and thus cannot introduce recursion by themselves, so they do not require investigation for Rule 17.2. Investigators should trace the call graph starting from each listed call to detect any indirect recursion back to digest_calc_hash.
